problem . Let’s explore how it works below.
We need to find the length of the longest subsequence which is common in both the strings.
Subsequence is a sequence that can be derived from another sequence by deleting some elements

Input: "elephant", "erepat"
Output: 5
Explanation: The longest substring is "eepat".

Input: "houdini", "hdupti"
Output: 3
Explanation: The longest substring is "hui".
as a reference, we need to determine the probablity. Typically when comparing 2 characters, there are 2 probablities:

Let’s go in depth on the subproblem above. There is an additional of
because we have a match on the first character. The second part
means that for the next iteration where we’re moving to the second character for each string.
Since it doesn’t match, we can say that
As the characters doesn’t match, we need to stay at the same character for one of the string and move to the next character for the other.
Hence, if we manage to solve the subproblems, the end result would be the maximum value of these 3 subproblems.

function lcs(str1, str2, i1, i2) {
  if (i1 === str1.length || i2 === str2.length)
    return 0

  let result1 = 0;
  if (str1[i1] == str2[i2]) {
    result1 = 1 + lcs(str1, str2, i1 + 1, i2 + 1);
  }

  const result2 = lcs(str1, str2, i1 + 1, i2);
  const result3 = lcs(str1, str2, i1, i2 + 1);

  return Math.max(result1, result2, result3);
}
So the solution is not optimised. Why would I say that? This is because, we are running certain calculation twice or more. Let’s take a look at the

lcs(0,0)
    /             |             \
lcs(0,1)        lcs(1,0)        lcs(1,1)
  |               |               |
  |-lcs(0,2)      |-lcs(1,1)      |-lcs(1,2)
  |-lcs(1,1)      |-lcs(2,0)      |-lcs(2,1)
  |-lcs(1,2)      |-lcs(2,1)      |-lcs(2,2)
at least twice, etc. This is a case of overlapping subproblems. Hence in order to optimise this solution we can use
. Below shows the code algorithm to achieve this approach.

const dp = {};

function lcs(str1: string, str2: string, i1: number, i2: number): number {
  if (i1 === str1.length || i2 === str2.length)
    return 0;

  if (!(i1 in dp) && !(i2 in dp[i1])) {  // We'll only solve this problem if we haven't already done it
    let result1 = 0;
    if (str1[i1] === str2[i2]) {
      result1 = 1 + lcs(str1, str2, i1 + 1, i2 + 1);
    }

    const result2 = lcs(str1, str2, i1 + 1, i2);
    const result3 = lcs(str1, str2, i1, i2 + 1);
    dp[i1] = { [i2]: Math.max(result1, result2, result3) };
  }

  return dp[i1][i2];
}
As we can see above, it is almost the same as
except for the additonal variable to store already-solved subproblems. This would ensure that we don’t run the recursion again to solve something that was already solved.

We then need to find the cell which doesn’t have any dependency as our starting point as we will have our first answer there. That would be the last cell
. And we slowly move our way up to the rest of the cells until we reach the first cell
which will give us our final answer.
rows and columns are our base conditions where we return

function lcs(str1, str2) {
  const dp = {};

  for (let i = str1.length; i  > 0; --i) {
    for (let j = str2.length; j > 0; --j) {
      if str1[i - 1] == str2[j - 1] {
        dp[i1] = { [i2]: Math.max(1 + dp[i-1][j-1], dp[i][j+1], dp[i+1][j]) };
      } else {
        dp[i1] = { [i2]: Math.max(dp[i][j+1], dp[i+1][j]) };
      }
    }
  }

  return dp[0][0];
}
